content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Augusta Canal National Landmark in Georgia is listed on the National Historic Register and designated as a significant resource. It boasts excellent water quality, historic landscapes, and architecturally significant structures. The Augusta Canal Area includes three national historic districts (Harrisburg, Laney Walker, and Greene Street), two national historic landmarks (Stallings Island and Meadow Garden), and offers undeveloped recreational opportunities with scenic vistas and excellent water quality. The Augusta Canal Area represents the development of the cotton textile industry and agriculture in the South. The transformation into an industrial economy was driven by the Augusta Canal. Significant sites related to various historical events and diverse communities are located in the area. Despite efforts by Georgia, political challenges remain. The Augusta Canal Area's cultural, historical, natural, and recreational resources are at risk of being lost without Federal Government assistance. The Secretary of the Interior has designated the landmark as a priority for protection, and there is a strong desire from local, regional, and State agencies, businesses, and private citizens to work together to preserve and enhance the area. The Augusta Canal National Historic Landmark is a priority for protection, with local, regional, and State agencies, businesses, and private citizens working together to preserve and enhance its resources for the future. The purpose of this Act is to establish a cooperative management framework for the Augusta Canal in Georgia to retain, enhance, and interpret its significant features while promoting economic development. The Augusta Canal National Heritage Area boundaries are also defined. The Augusta Canal National Heritage Area is established in Georgia and South Carolina, including lands commonly known as the Augusta Canal. The boundaries are defined in the Augusta Canal Master Plan. The Secretary of the Interior will publish a detailed description and map of the boundaries for the Augusta Canal National Heritage Area in the Federal Register. The Augusta Canal Commission is established. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed by the Secretary, including five from the Augusta Canal Authority, one from the mayor of Augusta, Georgia, and one from the Georgia congressional delegation. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed by the Secretary, including representation from Augusta, Georgia, recommendations from the Governors of Georgia and South Carolina, and the election of a chairman from among its members to fill vacancies in the same manner as the original appointment. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed by the Secretary, including representation from Augusta, Georgia, recommendations from the Governors of Georgia and South Carolina, and the election of a chairman from among its members to fill vacancies in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Augusta Canal Commission is tasked with preparing a management plan for the Heritage Area within a year of the Act's enactment. The plan must integrate federal, state, and local plans, including the Augusta Canal Master Plan, to protect and enhance the area's cultural, natural, scenic, and recreational resources. The Augusta Canal Commission is responsible for preparing a management plan for the Heritage Area, focusing on the interpretation of cultural, natural, scenic, and recreational resources. The Secretary can provide technical and financial assistance for the plan's preparation, and must approve or disapprove the plan within 180 days of receipt, considering local support from a variety of landowners. The Augusta Canal Commission is tasked with creating a management plan for the Heritage Area, with a focus on cultural, natural, scenic, and recreational resources. The plan must be approved or disapproved by the Secretary within 180 days, considering support from various stakeholders in the area. Key factors for approval include consistency with economic activity, partnership potential, and protection of private property rights. The Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the management plan to the Secretary for approval if disapproved, with reasons and recommendations provided. The Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the management plan to the Secretary for approval within 180 days. Upon approval, the Secretary and the Commission will implement the plan through cooperative agreements. The Secretary can enter cooperative agreements with Georgia, political subdivisions, Augusta Canal Commission, or others to implement the management plan. Economic development efforts should align with the goals of the Augusta Canal Master Plan. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARDS. This Act does not impose stricter regulations on the Heritage Area than those in place before its establishment. No Federal agency can introduce more stringent regulations solely due to the Heritage Area's creation. SEC. 7. DUTIES OF OTHER FEDERAL ENTITIES. SEC. 7. Duties of other Federal entities include consulting, cooperating, and coordinating activities with the Secretary and Augusta Canal Commission to ensure no adverse effects on the Heritage Area. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out this Act.
